I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  regional  transaction  technical  assistance (TA) facility  will  support  clean  energy 
projects for (i) project feasibility and due diligence, (ii) capacity development and implementation 
support, and (iii) cross-departmental green energy project pipeline development. For (i), the 
facility will conduct project preparation activities for the Grid Reinforcement Project with Additional 
Financing  (Cambodia),  Climate  Change  Policy  Program  (Philippines),  and  Power  Grid 
Strengthening Project (Timor-Leste). For (ii), project implementation support will be provided for 
Sustainable  and  Reliable  Energy  Access  Program  (Indonesia)  and  Sustainable  Energy 
Transition–DAMRI E-bus Project (Indonesia).1 For (iii), the TA facility will develop a pipeline of 
green energy projects for investment under the One-ADB framework, involving collaboration 
among the Energy Division (SEEN) and the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division of the Southeast Asia Department, Office of Public-Private Partnership (OPPP), and 
Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD).2 
 
2.  These energy sector projects require common preparatory due diligence activities such 
as  preliminary  technical  design,  economic  analysis,  financial  assessment,  safeguards  due 
diligence, procurement risk assessment, and strategic planning. Project preparation also requires 
climate risk and vulnerability assessment, climate finance analysis, and gender analysis and 
action planning. By combining these activities into an integrated TA facility, consulting resources 
can be shared in a more optimal manner among various countries and projects to reduce TA 
administration costs and maximize the efficiency of using scarce TA resources.3 
 
3.  Continued  urbanization,  the  increasing  size  of  middle  class  population,  and  rapidly 
growing commercial and industrial activities have contributed to  a significant upsurge in electricity 
demand in Southeast Asia. Reliable and affordable electricity supply to meet this demand has 
been and remains a key enabler of inclusive and sustainable growth. This is even more important 
for the recovery from the severe impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.   
 
4.  The Southeast Asian countries also need to address the long-term socioeconomic impacts 
induced  by  global  climate  change  to  achieve  sustainable  development.  Under  the  Paris 
Agreement, each country has committed to specific national greenhouse gas (GHG) emission 
reduction targets. As electricity production based on fossil fuels is one of the largest GHG emitters, 
countries are adopting strategies to a just transition toward renewable energy-based electricity 
supply and undertake demand-side management measures to conserve electricity. 
 
5.  Recent technological innovations have led to a rapid reduction of solar and wind electricity 
production costs by almost threefold compared to 10 years ago. This cost reduction, coupled with 
enabling policies (such as feed-in-tariff) and market innovations (such as solar auctions), has led 
 
1  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Cambodia, 2021–2023. Manila; ADB. 2020. Country Operations 
Business Plan: Indonesia, 2021–2023. Manila; and  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Timor-Leste, 
2021–2023. Manila. 
2  Future support by the TA facility is anticipated for the National Project on Energy Storage for Utility-Scale Solar Plants 
(Cambodia), Clean Electricity Supply Program (Indonesia), Geothermal Power Expansion Project (Indonesia), Power 
Interconnection Project (Indonesia), and Rural Electrification Project (Viet Nam).  
3  In October 2018, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a regional transaction TA facility phase 1 (ADB. 
2018. Technical Assistance to the Southeast Asia Energy Sector Development, Investment Planning and Capacity 
Building Facility. Manila), which supports a series of energy projects and programs in the Southeast Asia countries. 
This proposed TA facility is a second phase, which will continue to support countries in preparing energy investment 
projects for approval by ADB and the governments during the period 2022–2024.

2   
to a substantial increase in solar and wind capacity worldwide. Electric battery and energy storage 
technologies  are  also  becoming  more  available  and  affordable  solutions  to  balance  the 
intermittent solar and wind power supply and to improve network reliability and stability. Electric 
vehicles are being increasingly promoted to reduce GHG emissions in the transport sector. A 
faster diffusion of such technological advancements creates increasingly favorable conditions in 
Southeast Asia for transitioning to energy systems with lower carbon emissions. The private 
sector is already playing a key role in introducing innovation and scaling up investment, with public 
sector interventions that are largely focused on improving the policy and regulatory environment 
for private sector participation and market-oriented sector development. The proposed TA facility 
will help Southeast Asia countries to accelerate the adoption of these innovations such as the 
integration of battery energy storage systems into transmission grids to handle higher shares of 
wind- and solar-based electricity supply and installation of more solar and wind power stations to 
achieve a just transition toward sustainable energy sector development.  
 
6.  The series of investment projects to be supported under the TA facility represent a 
balanced mix of investment proposals that will (i) continue to strengthen and expand power 
system capacities to serve the increasing demand and (ii) utilize renewable energy (solar, wind, 
and waste-to-energy), and develop technologies for their integration into a greener electricity 
system. The TA facility, therefore, helps the Southeast Asia countries to meet fast growing 
electricity demand in a sustainable manner. 
 
7.  In supporting the transition to a greener, lower carbon, and inclusive energy sector 
development, the TA facility is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030.4 The ensuing projects will 
contribute to increasing access to reliable electricity supply to meet basic needs and improve 
quality of life (operational priority [OP] 1), skills development for women and productive use of 
women’s time (OP2), tacking climate change at its core and building disaster resilience smart 
transmission  and  distribution  networks  (OP3),  promoting  rural  development  (OP5),  and 
strengthening institutional capacity for the governments (OP6). It is anticipated that the TA facility 
will also support projects that enable livable cities and urban development, contributing to OP4. 
The  TA  strongly  supports  renewable  energy  projects  in  the  Southeast  Asian  countries, 
contributing  to  tackling  climate  change  and  enhancing  energy-environment  sustainability  in 
accordance with ADB’s announcement to provide $100 billion climate financing by 2030.5 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Project feasibility studies and due diligence prepared. For projects listed in 
para. 1 item (i), the TA facility will support their project preparation activities, including: (i) technical 
feasibility studies, design, and cost estimates; (ii) economic analysis; (iii) financial management 
assessments  and  financial  analysis;  (iv) procurement  risk  assessments  and  preparation  of 
strategic procurement plans, and preparation of bidding documents; (v) gender analysis and 
preparation of gender action plans;  (vi) risk assessment and management plan; (vii) preparation 
of safeguards documents on environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples; (viii) 
integrity due diligence; (ix) initial poverty and social analysis; (x) climate and disaster resilience 
measures, climate risk and adaptation assessment, and disaster risk assessment; (xi) climate 
financing  analysis;  (xii)  sector  assessment;  and  (xiii)  other  documents  required  for  project 
approval.  
 
4 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030. Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  
5 ADB. 2021. ADB Raises 2019–2030 Climate Finance Ambition to $100 Billion. News release. 13 October.

3 
9.  Output  2:  Capacity  development  and  implementation  support  for  investment 
projects provided. Capacity development support for executing and implementing agencies is 
particularly important at the beginning of project implementation before the project implementation 
consultants commence services. Further support will also be provided as more specific needs for 
capacity building emerge during project implementation. These activities may include, among 
others: (i) overall project management with quality control; (ii) procurement-related tasks; (iii) 
implementation  of  environmental  and  social  safeguards  measures  and  plans;  (iv)  project 
monitoring, reporting, and public consultation; and (v) institutional gender mainstreaming. In 
addition, the TA facility will support implementation tasks requiring special expertise, such as 
climate and disaster risk assessment and climate change mitigation and adaptation measures. 
Immediate support will be provided for projects in para. 1, item (ii). 
 
10.  Output 3: Pipeline of cross-departmental green energy projects developed. The TA 
facility will support the Southeast Asian countries to (i) develop relatively more challenging 
renewable electricity generation projects such as offshore wind, floating solar, and waste-to-
energy for electricity generation; and (ii) integrate the renewable electricity generated into flexible 
and smart transmission and distribution grids, including the use of battery energy storage systems. 
Activities will include conducting prefeasibility studies to ascertain technical and economic viability, 
and proposing technological solutions for integration into the national electricity system. As a 
result,  a  pipeline  of  renewable  energy  projects  will  be  prepared  for  investment,  involving 
collaboration among SEEN, OPPP, and PSOD under the One-ADB approach. Projects in the 
pipeline will be supported jointly by both sovereign and nonsovereign operations, such that 
investment for grid integration and common facilities will be supported by SEEN, while investment 
for renewable generating capacities may be tendered out for the private sector with OPPP and 
PSOD support. Projects to be supported under this output currently include Waste-to-Energy 
Project (Cambodia), Off-shore Wind Power Project (Thailand), and Battery Energy Storage 
System Project (Viet Nam). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $2.76 million, of which (i) $2.50 million will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7: $1.50 million, TASF-other 
sources: $1.00 million); and (ii) $0.26 million will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate 
Change Fund.6 The key expenditure items and indicative TA budget allocation per outputs are 
listed in Appendix 1.  
 
12.  The TA facility scope is expected to be expanded to support additional projects identified 
during future ADB country programming missions, consistent with the TA’s outputs. The TA facility 
will be replenished from time to time as funds are required and identified, including those from 
cofinancing sources and ADB-administered trust funds. 
  
13.  The  governments  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff,  office  and 
communication facilities, and other in-kind contributions. The governments were informed that 
approval of the TA facility does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA facility and will administer and implement it 
through SEEN. Output 1 activities that are specific for any ensuing project will commence only 
 
6  Established by ADB. The Climate Change Fund allocation of $260,000 was approved on 14 May 2021.

4   
after  ADB  approves  the  project concept  paper  of  the  ensuing  project. Other  activities  will 
commence upon TA facility approval.7 The TA facility will be implemented over 37 months from 
December 2021 to December 2024.  
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

16.  Consulting services. The TA facility is estimated to require a total of 161 person-months 
of consulting services (111 person-months of international expertise and 50 person-months of 
national expertise). A consulting firm will be engaged to deliver required services for the 4-year 
Philippines Climate Change Policy Program as this policy-based loan program has its unique 
consulting requirements. The TA facility will engage a technical firm through a framework contract 
to help deliver technical assessments for TA activities especially for Outputs 1 and 3 because 
they require similar technical and engineering assessments to improve procurement efficiency. 
Framework  agreements  will  be  developed  to  engage  individual  consultants,  who  will  be 
responsible for delivering due diligence on safeguards, and economic and financial assessments. 
This is indicated in the implementation arrangements table above and detailed in the Terms of 
Reference for Consultants.8 ADB will engage all consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.  
 
7  ADB will obtain a no-objection in writing from the relevant country prior to conducting or financing any TA activities 
(unless it is simple collection of information/materials either in the public domain or from an official source) in the 
territory of such country. 
8  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,760,000 on a grant basis for 
the Southeast Asia Energy Sector Development, Investment Planning, and Capacity Building 
Facility, Phase 2, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
